docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Report Faults Individuals For Abuses in Iraq A new Army report concludes that flaws in military detention operations did not directly contribute to the abuses at Abu Ghraib prison. The report blamed the ''unauthorized actions taken by a few individuals, coupled with the failure of a few leaders to provide adequate monitoring, supervision and leadership over those soldiers.'' A10

docs.lead_paragraph: State audits that found $20 million in overpayments to a company providing health insurance to poor children were ''vastly inaccurate,'' said Dominic Hagger, a senior vice president of the company, Clarendon Insurance Group of New York City. Texas officials said poor management of the Children's Health Insurance Program had resulted in excessive payments to Clarendon. In a letter to state officials, Mr. Hagger said the company had provided ''tremendous value'' and ''extremely efficient'' health insurance. Steve Barnes (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Insurer Defends Record

docs.abstract: Clarendon Insurance Group defends itself against Texas audits that found $20 million in overpayments to company, which provides health insurance to poor children; state officials cite poor management of program (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Rebels in Iraq Claim More Kidnappings Insurgents in Iraq said they had kidnapped six more foreign hostages, all truck drivers, and threatened to behead one every 72 hours unless their employer, a Kuwaiti company, Universal Services, shut down operations. None of the countries of those kidnapped have soldiers in Iraq; instead, the target seemed to be the reconstruction effort. A1 Saudi police discovered the frozen head of Paul M. Johnson Jr., the American hostage decapitated last month. The head was found in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, during a raid of the suspected hideout of a purported leader of Al Qaeda. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is nothing flashy about Erica Kennedy, the first-time novelist who plumbs the shallows of the hip-hop glitterati in the new book ''Bling.'' Sure, her striking model looks and soaring cheekbones stand out, even amid the head-turning crowd at the subterranean Mercer Kitchen in SoHo. She is delicate-boned and languidly self-assured in an olive-green sweater, a lacy camisole and tan corduroys. She wears the tiniest jeweled crucifix around her neck. Not blinged-out, this woman.
docs.abstract: Lynda Richardson Public Lives column discusses Erica Kennedy's new book Bling, which is about world of hip-hop music; photo (M)
